content.description: Retinitis pigmentosa is a rare genetic disorder that causes the breakdown of cells in the eye, resulting in vision loss. Worldwide, the occurrence of retinitis pigmentosa in the population is approximately <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> in <math alttext="4,000" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>000</mn></math>. However, on a small group of islands in the Atlantic Ocean, the occurrence is approximately <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> in <math alttext="58" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>58</mn></math>.
content.question: Which of the following best explains how the occurrence of a rare, genetic disorder can be so much more prevalent on a small group of islands as compared with the rest of the world?

choices.label: An unusually high number of individuals with the disease initially colonized the islands, and there has been little immigration to the islands since that time.
Individuals on the islands evolved adaptations to the vision loss, and because the disorder does not affect an individualâ€™s fitness, the disorder remains in the population.
The population of individuals on the islands has greater genetic diversity compared with the worldwide population, resulting in a larger number of individuals with genetic disorders.
The mutation rate is greater in the population of individuals on the islands than in the worldwide population, resulting in a greater incidence of rare disorders.

content.answer: An unusually high number of individuals with the disease initially colonized the islands, and there has been little immigration to the islands since that time.
